desc: Day School building enlarged to provide accommodation for boarders.
New two-storey stone school building constructed.
Operational Agreement signed between the Bishop of Qu’Appelle and the Federal Government for the future maintenance and management of Gordon’s Boarding School.
New frame structure added to the school.
Cadets introduced at Gordon’s IRS.
New modern school building constructed.
Boarding school burned down. New building erected.
Administration of the school transferred from the Diocese of Qu’Appelle to the Indian & Eskimo Welfare Commission of the Anglican Church of Canada.
1947-1953: School closed for long periods due to water and mechanical problems.
Classroom block, with a basement auditorium, was constructed separate from the main building.
First pupils sent to high school at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.
Boy Scouts, Cubs, Girl Guides and Brownies formed at the school.
Operation Agreement signed between the Missionary Society of the Anglican Church of Canada and the Federal Government.
Additional school block constructed, with gymnasium.

Government assumed direct responsibility for the administration of the school. The boarding portion became known as the Gordon Student Residence and the classroom portion the Gordon Day School. Domestic staff came under federal jurisdiction.
The Gordon Band entered into its first Tuition Agreement, with the Last Mountain School Division.
Advisory Board of the Residence was formed.
New admissions policy goes into effect at the residence.
The Advisory Board members proposed a student policy drafted by the Education Authority.
Gordon’s Student Residence was closed and the main building demolished.

additionalInformation.notes: An employee is charged with attempted buggery and buggery against boarding pupils at the Residence. He is convicted and sentenced.
An employee is convicted of common assault on a girl pupil. Two months after his conviction, he was still at the school, because the Principal had difficulty replacing him.

Enquiries into the case of pupil suffering from a sexually-transmitted disease reveals incidents of buggery and other sexual behaviour at the school. The pupil confesses that he was buggered by an ex-pupil of about 19 years of age who was hired as a supervisor. The Supervisor was sentenced to six months in jail.
A staff member is sent to jail for tampering with Indian boys in his charge.
A Supervisor is fined for making a pupil pregnant.
A former Principal is arrested in New Brunswick. He is charged with the sexual assault of 13 male students at Gordon’s IRS. He pleads guilty.

The Principal of Gordon’s IRS reports that over the past two years, some staff members have been either sexually abusing pupils or sexually involved with Indian men on the Reserve. Some parents are objecting to sending their children to the school and the female staff members feel that the immoral behaviour of some employees reflects on them.

Four girls charge the Principal with inappropriate touching and inappropriate behaviour. The Principal is cleared of the charges, but informs the Government that he no longer wishes to work at the School.

Senior staff members have suggested that an individual was having immoral relationships with some of the boys in his care while he was employed as a Boys’ Supervisor at Gordon’s IRS. These allegations were confirmed by several of the students he abused. The Church authorities removed him from direct contact with the boys and advised the Principal to keep an eye on him. He later transferred to another school, from which he was dismissed. He was listed under the Church’s Confidential Character Code as unfit for further employment.

A Child Care Worker received a written reprimand for taking students ou tof residence without consent and for having students visit his private staff room. He was informed that there had been gossip regarding his involvement in drinking and homosexual activities with the students at another reserve.
A Child Care Worker at the residence was suspended pending investigation for sexually harassing a number of female students.
A janitor at the school made sexual advances to a female student.Criminalchargeswere laid.
A Subpoena to a Witness was issued in the case of sexual assault on a female student.
An employee was suspended pending investigation into alleged sexual harassment of female students.
Allegations are made against an employee at Gordon’s IRS for ill treatment of the children.
A Parent wishes to return a boy to the school, but wants assurance that the Principal will not strap the boy again.

It is reported that, as punishment for truancy, the Principal had students confined to a cell, lashed, fed bread and water and given short hair cuts. The Principal explained that the children were placed in the infirmary, not a cell.

The General Superintendent of Indian Agencies received a report from the School Inspector stating that the teacher of grade 1, was locking the children in the classroom, and the Kindergarten’s classroom was being operated in the basement.
Questions are raised regarding the humanitarian qualifications of the current Principal of Gordon’s IRS. According to information gathered, the students were terrified of him.
The Superintendent of Education received reports that the Principal of Gordon’s IRS was cruel in his punishment of students. The Principal resigned.
A Parent informs the school that his children will not return to the school because they are allegedly being strapped daily by a female employee.
The Parents of a pupil complain to the Principal that a supervisor strapped their child with a brush and left marks on his body. The Principal gave assurance that this would not occur again.

A Gordon’s IRS staff member informs the Principal that he witnessed a Child Care Worker striking a student on the face and kicking him in the side. The student alleged that he had been beaten with a stick just prior to this. The student had marks and welts on his body.
The Senior Boys’ Child Care Worker slapped a student across the face.
A Child Care Worker was reprimanded for using bodily force in order to discipline the students.
A complaint was made by a parent alleging that a school employee used excessive force in disciplining a student at the residence.
A student was examined by a doctor after having allegedly been struck on the left ear by a school employee.

The same Child Care Worker was reprimanded and given notice of suspension for physically assaulting a student and causing bodily harm. Another Child Care Worker, alleged to have struck a student on the head with a stick, was told that any physical abuse would not be tolerated.
A Child Care Worker was reprimanded for injuring a student with a broom and reminded that the use of physical force against students would not be tolerated.
An incident report alleged that a student had been hit by the driver of the bus.
The grandfather of a student alleged that his grandson had been hit at school.
Students alleged that a pupil was thrown around by a teacher.
A teacher was accused of shaking and throwing a student.
A complaint was received about an employee getting too rough with a student.
It was reported that an employee was pushing the children when he wanted them to do something.
student alleged that her supervisors slapped her across the face.

A Child Care Worker allegedly banged a student’s head against a wall.
A student claimed that he was constantly being slapped or picked on by a residence employee.
Allegation is made that a Child Care Worker used physical force against a student.

A student accused a teacher at the Punnichy High School of slapping his face. Both student and teacher later agreed that it was really just a tap on the mouth to express disapproval of the students words.
An Advisory Board meeting held in December notes an oral reprimand issued to a Child Care Worker for unnecessary and unethical use of corporal punishment.
A school employee choked and pushed a student.
Complaints were made against a child care worker, including an allegation that he used the bigger boys to discipline the smaller boys in the dorm.
A residence employee received a written reprimand for unethical and unnecessary use of corporal punishment of students.
Students were made to kneel in a child care worker’s office holding 15k weights.

A pupil is sent to the Psychopathic Ward of the Regina General Hospital after he stabbed another student at the school.
A student attacked another student with a carving knife while working in the kitchen.
A student was admitted to the Qu’Appelle Indian Hospital after repeatedly forcing himself sexually on other boys.
A student was referred to the Fort Qu’Appelle Indian Hospital after passing sexual notes and drawings to girls in the school.
A Corporal Punishment and Detention Log, kept at the Gordon’s IRS, reveals a number of physical and sexual incidents between students.
It was reported that a male student was physically abusing a female student.

A number of students claimed to have been bothered in a sexual as well as physical manner by bigger boys in the Senior dorm.
A student was accused of stripping another student in the dorm and hiding her pyjamas.

In 1939, a student ran away from the Gordon’s Indian Residential School and froze to death before he was found.

From 1975 on, the Gordon’s Student Residence had an Advisory Board composed of members of the Gordon Band. The Board advised the Residence Administrator on the operation of the residence and assisted in formulating policy on a variety of items affecting the students and staff, including admissions policy, staffing and student discipline.
On January 9, 1989, the Punnichy Elementary School informed Parents and Guardians of a personal safety program being implemented in Grade Two. This program addressed the issue of sexual abuse.

In 1991, a member of the Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations was informed that the Government would be working with aboriginal communities to address healing related to past child abuse in the residential schools. In that year, too, the Government released a formal protocol respecting child abuse. It included guidelines for identifying and reporting child abuse cases. Theses guidelines were sent to all residential schools. Inservice training was provided for staff, including those at Gordon’s.
